newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong gold ends higher on Tokyo shortcovering.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong gold ends higher on Tokyo shortcovering.

text.p: Hong Kong spot gold ended up on Tuesday from New York's previous close on shortcovering from Tokyo punters and buying from Europe, bullion dealers said.
Bullion ended at US$342.00/50 an ounce on Tuesday against New York's US$341.30/90 close on Monday.
"There was a lot of volume done in Tokyo, everyone got caught bullish, and with the massive selloff in dollar/yen, (gold) shortcovering started," said one senior bullion dealer.

The dollar briefly dipped below 112 yen in late Tokyo trade on Tuesday, down more than three yen from its New York close on Monday due to expectations of a narrowing interest rate gap between the United States and Japan.
"Punters saw the opportunity and that triggered some shortcovering in gold," another dealer noted.
When European markets opened later in the Hong Kong trading day, a weaker mark sparked gold buying, dealers said.
Dealers saw $340 per ounce as remaining the psychological support level, with any prices below $340 seen as a bargain for physical buyers.
Gold would continue to play the range between $340 and $343 per ounce, traders said.
Local gold ended HK$10 lower at HK$3,165 a tael.
The carry over charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society dropped to -5.00 from its previous fix at -4.00.
